speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: Good afternoon.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: Thanks very much for being here.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: I know that a number of you will want to talk about the details of our announcement today, and I am happy to do that in a few minutes.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: But because monetary policy affects everyone, I want to start with a plain-English summary of how the economy is doing, what my colleagues and I at the Federal Reserve are trying to do, and why.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: The main takeaway is that the economy is doing very well.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: Most people who want to find jobs are finding them, and unemployment and inflation are low.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: Interest rates have been low for some years while the economy has been recovering from the financial crisis.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: For the past few years, we have been gradually raising interest rates, and along the way we’ve tried to explain the reasoning behind our decisions.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: In particular, we think that gradually returning interest rates to a more normal level as the economy strengthens is the best way the Fed can help sustain an environment in which American households and businesses can thrive.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: Today, we’ve taken another step in that process by raising our target range for the federal funds rate by ¼ of a percentage point.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: My colleagues and I meet eight times a year and take a fresh look each time at what is happening in the economy and consider whether our policy needs adjusting.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: We don’t put our interest rate decisions on hold or on autopilot, because the economy can always evolve in unexpected ways.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: History has shown that moving interest rates either too quickly or too slowly can lead to bad economic outcomes.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: We think the outcomes are likely to be better overall if we are as clear as possible about what we are likely to do and why.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: To that end, we try to give a sense of our expectations for how the economy will evolve and how our policy stance may change.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: As Chairman, I hope to foster a public conversation about what the Fed is doing to support a strong and resilient economy.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: And one practical step in doing so is to have a press conference like this after every one of our scheduled FOMC meetings.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: And we’re going to do that beginning in January.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: That will give us more opportunities to explain our actions and to answer your questions.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: I want to point out that having twice as many press conferences does not signal anything about the timing or pace of future interest rate changes.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: This change is only about improving communications.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: My FOMC colleagues and I will also continue to issue our economic projections on the existing quarterly schedule.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: Now, let me go into more detail over developments in the economy, our economic projections, and our policy decision.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: Economic growth appears to have picked up in the current quarter, largely reflecting a bounceback in household spending.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: Business investment continues to grow strongly, and the overall outlook for growth remains favorable.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: Several factors support this assessment: Fiscal policy is boosting the economy, ongoing job gains are raising incomes and confidence, foreign economies continue to expand, and overall financial conditions remain accommodative.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: These observations are consistent with the projections that Committee participants submitted for this meeting.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: The median projection for the growth of real GDP is 2.8 percent this year, 2.4 percent next year, and 2 percent in 2020.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: Compared with the projections made in March, this median growth path is little changed.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: In the labor market, job gains averaged 180,000 per month over the past three months, well above the pace needed in the longer run to provide jobs for new entrants into the workforce.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: The unemployment rate declined over the past two months and stood at 3.8 percent in May, its lowest level in nearly two decades.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: Meanwhile, the labor force participation rate has been roughly unchanged since late 2013.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: That is a positive sign, given that the aging of our June 13, 2018 population is putting downward pressure on the participation rate.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: And we expect the job market Chairman Powell’s Press Conference FINAL to remain strong.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: As you can see in our Summary of Economic Projections, the median of Committee participants’ projections for the unemployment rate stands at 3.6 percent in the fourth quarter of this year and runs at 3.5 percent over the next two years, a percentage point below the median estimate of its longer-run normal rate.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: This median path is just a bit lower than that from March.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: After many years of running below our 2 percent longer-run objective, inflation has recently moved close to that level.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: Indeed, overall consumer prices, as measured by the price index for personal consumption expenditures, increased 2 percent over the 12 months ending in April.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: The core PCE index, which excludes prices of energy and food and tends to be a better indicator of future inflation, rose 1.8 percent over the same period.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: As we had expected, inflation moved up as the unusually low readings from last March dropped out of the calculation.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: The recent inflation data have been encouraging, but after many years of inflation below our objective, we do not want to declare victory.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: We want to ensure that inflation remains near our symmetric 2 percent longer-run goal on a sustained basis.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: As we note in our Statement of Longer-Run Goals and Monetary Policy Strategy, the Committee would be concerned if inflation were running persistently above or below our 2 percent objective.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: Of course, many factors affect inflation—some temporary and others more lasting—and at any given time inflation may be above or below 2 percent.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: For example, the recent rise in oil prices will likely push inflation somewhat above 2 percent in coming months.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: But that transitory development should have little, if any, consequence for inflation over the next few years.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: The median of participants’ projections for inflation runs at 2.1 percent through 2020.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: Relative to the March projections, the median inflation projection is a little higher this year and next.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: As I mentioned, today we took another step in gradually scaling back monetary policy accommodation by raising the target range for the federal funds rate by ¼ percentage point, bringing it to 1¾ to 2 percent.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: We also made some changes to our policy statement, reflecting that policy normalization is proceeding broadly as we have expected.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: None of these changes signals a change in our policy views.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: For example, we removed the language stating that “the federal funds rate is likely to remain, for some time, below levels that are expected to prevail in the longer run.” Since we introduced that language a few years ago, the economy has strengthened, and the Committee has raised the federal funds rate from near 0 to 1¾ to 2 percent.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: As we continue to note in our statement, we expect to make further gradual increases in that rate.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: As a result, if the economy evolves broadly as we anticipate, the federal funds rate will, over the next year or so, move well within the range of estimates of the normal long-run level.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: Therefore, we thought that now is an appropriate time to remove this forward guidance from our policy statement.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: We continue to believe that a gradual approach for increasing the federal funds rate will best promote a sustained expansion of economic activity, strong labor market conditions, and inflation near our symmetric 2 percent goal.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: We are aware that raising rates too slowly might raise the risk that monetary policy would need to tighten abruptly down the road in response to an unexpectedly sharp increase in inflation or financial excesses, jeopardizing the economic expansion.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: Conversely, if we raise interest rates too rapidly, the economy could weaken, and inflation could continue to run persistently below our objective.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: The Committee’s gradual approach is reflected in participants’ projections for the appropriate path for the federal funds rate.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: The median projection for the federal funds rate is 2.4 percent at the end of this year, 3.1 percent at the end of 2019, and 3.4 percent at the end of June 13, 2018 2020.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: By 2020, the median federal funds rate is modestly above its estimated longer-run level.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: Chairman Powell’s Press Conference FINAL These projections are very similar to those made in March.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: Although the median federal funds rate edged up this year and next, most participants did not revise their projections.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: I’ll conclude by mentioning two additional matters.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: First, our program for reducing our balance sheet, which began in October, is proceeding smoothly.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: Barring a material and unexpected weakening in the outlook, this program will proceed on schedule, and our balance sheet will continue to shrink.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: As we have said, changing the target range for the federal funds rate is our primary means of adjusting the stance of monetary policy.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: And, finally, as discussed in the minutes of our May meeting, we’re making a small technical adjustment in one of our tools for implementing monetary policy.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: To keep the federal funds rate in the target range, we rely on the rate of interest on excess reserves, or the IOER rate.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: Up until now, we have set the IOER rate at the top of the target range for the federal funds rate.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: In recent months, the federal funds rate has moved up toward the IOER rate as short-term interest rates have risen more generally.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: So to move the federal funds rate closer to the middle of the target range, we are now setting the IOER rate 5 basis points below the upper end of the target range.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: This minor technical adjustment has no bearing on the appropriate path for the federal funds rate or financial conditions more generally.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: Thanks for listening, and I’ll be happy to take your questions.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: Sure.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: So since—I wouldn’t say anything has happened since March to really change the way I’m thinking about inflation or the way the Committee’s thinking about inflation.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: We’ve seen inflation move very gradually up toward our 2 percent objective.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: And part of that has been just idiosyncratic things dropping out from last March, which were holding inflation—measured inflation—down.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: Part of it is just that continued tightening in the labor market and the economy more broadly is pushing inflation up.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: So we continue to think, and the Committee continues to think, that we are just about at our 2 percent goal but, as I mentioned, not ready to declare victory until we sustain that over time, which we haven’t done yet.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: You also asked about fiscal policy, and there’s a range of views on the Committee and, I think more broadly, a range of views among economists generally.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: But I can say that the Committee members—Committee participants—generally believe that the fiscal changes—and that includes both the tax cuts, individual and corporate, and the spending changes—will provide meaningful support to demand, significant support to demand over the course of the next three years.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: So it is—it makes sense that if you lower corporate tax rates and allow faster expensing of investment, you will encourage greater investment.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: That should drive productivity.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: That should increase potential output.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: So that really ought to happen as well.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: I think the amounts and the timing of that coming in are also quite uncertain.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: There’s also the possibility that there would be more labor supply from lower individual tax rates, again, in amounts and in timing that might be more uncertain.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: So that’s how the Committee generally is thinking about—about fiscal policy.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: So for many, many years, we’ve been far from maximum employment and stable prices, and so the need for accommodative policy has been—has been clear.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: Neutral meaning that interest rates are neither pushing the economy up nor trying to restrain it.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: So we know that we’re getting closer to that neutral level.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: We don’t have an exact sense of how that will be.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: So the Committee is discussing, very actively, the questions that you raise.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: So I think we’ll be very carefully looking at incoming data on inflation, on financial readings, and on the labor market.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: We have to acknowledge that there are always wide uncertainty bands around the level of, for example, the natural rate of unemployment.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: So I think we—we’ll be guided by incoming data on the economy and try to keep our minds open as we move forward.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: You know, the—our target for—our medium-term objective for inflation is 2 percent PCE inflation.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: We feel that that target has served the economy well, and I’m strongly committed to it.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: The Committee is strongly committed to it.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: The sort of barriers to making a material change to that would be—would be very high because, again, we think it’s fundamental, and we think it’s worked.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: You asked about price-level targeting and that sort of thing.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: You know, there are some ideas that sort of take cognizance of the fact that rates are lower, we’re near the zero lower bound, and that could put downward pressure on inflation expectations if we’re going to be down at the zero lower bound and, therefore, sort of undermine the credibility of the 2 percent inflation objective.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: So the idea is to have kind of a makeup.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: If you—if you’re below target for a while, you have a—you have a time of being above target.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: And the idea is to enhance the credibility of that 2 percent—that 2 percent target.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: This is an idea that’s been written about for many years.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: It’s not something that the Committee has looked at seriously.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: I imagine we will be having discussions about it, but—not something that we have on the calendar right now.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: I ought to start by saying that, you know, Congress has assigned us very important jobs and—you know, maximum employment, stable prices, we have a role in financial stability that we share with other agencies.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: Congress has very specifically given authority over trade to the executive branch, so I wouldn’t comment on any particular specific trade actions.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: I will say that we, of course, have—we have broad contacts in—among business leaders around the country.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: And the Reserve Bank presidents, in particular, have that.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: And so they report in the Beige Book and then in person at the FOMC meeting.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: And they do come back and they say that concerns about changes in trade policy are arising, I think it’s fair to say, and also that you’re beginning to hear reports of companies holding off on making investments and hiring people.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: So right now we don’t see that in the numbers at all.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: The economy is very strong.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: The labor market is strong.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: Growth is strong.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: We really don’t see it in the numbers.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: It’s just not there.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: But—so I would put it down as more of a risk.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: You know, first of all, that’s a—that’s a reasonable range, I think, of—it’s not that we’re all on the same number, but there are a range of views about potential growth.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: And there’s so much uncertainty around this.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: You know, we don’t—the thing about fiscal policy is, you don’t have thousands of incidents to, you know, to—you don’t have June 13, 2018 big data, in a way.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: You have very small data.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: You’ve got only a few instances here, so you have Chairman Powell’s Press Conference FINAL a lot of uncertainty around what the effects will be.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: They could be large.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: We hope they’re large.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: But I think our approach is going to be to watch and see and hope that, in fact, we do get significant effects to, you know, to potential growth out of the tax bill, and we’re just going to have to see.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: I think we’re looking at a reasonable range of estimates and we’re putting every—different participants are putting different estimates in and we’re going to be waiting and seeing.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: You know, what we’ve said in our Statement of Longer-Run Principles and Monetary Policy Strategy is that the Committee would be concerned if inflation were to run persistently above or below 2 percent, persistently above or below 2 percent.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: And that’s what we mean by symmetric.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: We’re looking at it equally on either side and it’s a matter of persistent overruns.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: We know that inflation is going to bounce around.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: For example, as I mentioned, later this summer there’s a good chance that headline inflation will move up above June 13, 2018 2 percent because of oil prices.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: Things buffet inflation back and forth, but—so we acknowledge Chairman Powell’s Press Conference FINAL that, we understand that—and if inflation were to persistently run above or below 2 percent, then we would be using our tools to try to move inflation back in the direction of the target.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: We do understand, though, that we don’t have the ability to precisely hit that target, so we expect that inflation will be above or below.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: And we just hope that that is—happens on a symmetric basis.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: I think what you should see is that the economy is continuing to make progress.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: The economy has strengthened so much since I joined the Fed, you know, in 2012 and even over the last couple of years.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: The economy is in a very different place.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: We— unemployment was 10 percent at the height of the crisis.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: It’s 3.8 percent now and moving lower.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: So really what you—the decision you see today is another sign that the U.S. economy is in great shape.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: Growth is strong, labor markets are strong, inflation is close to target, and that’s what you’re seeing.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: For many years, as I mentioned—many years—we had interest rates held low to support economic activity.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: And it’s been clear that as we’ve gotten closer to our statutory goals, we should normalize policy, and that’s really what we’ve been consistently doing for some years now.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: You know, wages have been gradually moving up.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: Earlier in the recovery, they were—there are many different wage measures, of course, but—so just—but just to generalize, wages were running roughly around 2 percent and they’ve moved gradually up into between 2 to 3 percent as the labor market has become stronger and stronger.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: I think it’s fair to say that some of us—and I certainly would have expected wages to react more to the very significant reduction in unemployment that we’ve had, as I mentioned, from 10 percent to 3.8 percent.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: Part of that can be explained by low productivity, which is something we’ve talked about at the Committee and elsewhere.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: So it’s a bit of a puzzle.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: I wouldn’t say it’s a mystery, but it’s a bit of a puzzle.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: And, frankly, I do think there’s a lot to like about low unemployment.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: And one of the things is—you will see—pretty much people who want to get jobs—not everybody—but people who want to get jobs, many of them will be able to get jobs.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: You will see wages go up.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: You’ll see people at the, sort of, the margins of the labor force having an opportunity to get back in work.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: They benefit from that.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: Society benefits from that.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: So there are a lot of things to really like, including higher wages, as you asked.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: Our role, though, is also to, you know, to make sure that—that maximum employment happens in a context of price stability and financial stability, which is why we’re gradually raising rates.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: You mentioned that unemployment moved down and inflation moved up by truly small amounts.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: If you look at the Summary of Economic Projections, things are moving by just a tick or even a semitick between now and March.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: And you asked, you know—I mean, I think we take a longer-run view that we’re shooting for—we’re aiming for—2 percent inflation—inflation around 2 percent.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: We know that it’ll be above or below.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: We’re not going to—we didn’t overreact, I think, to inflation being under 2 percent.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: We won’t overreact to it being over 2 percent.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: And I think we’ll always be using our tools to move inflation in the direction of the target, if it—if it leaves—if it moves away from the target persistently, as I mentioned.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: In terms of unemployment, you know, you have to acknowledge that we are—no one really knows with certainty what the level of the natural rate of unemployment is, the rate that is sustainable over a long period of time.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: And we know that probably that rate has declined as the U.S. population has become more educated, as it has become older.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: Older and more educated people have lower unemployment rates.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: We don’t know this with precision.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: So we have to be learning as we go.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: We’ve got to be looking at data and informed by what’s coming in.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: And as I mentioned, I think at the last press conference, estimates by the—by members of the Committee have moved down by a full percentage point since maybe 2012 as we’ve learned—as unemployment has dropped and inflation hasn’t really reacted.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: So I can’t give you a precise number, but I just—you know, we will be very much informed by incoming data.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: And this uncertainty is why—the fact that we live in that uncertainty is why we’ve been gradually raising rates.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: We’re not waiting for inflation to show up.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: We’re going ahead and moving gradually and June 13, 2018 trying to navigate between two risks, really.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: One would be moving too quickly—inflation never Chairman Powell’s Press Conference FINAL gets back to target if we do that.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: And the other is moving too slowly, and then we have—we have too much inflation or financial instability, and we have to raise quickly.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: And that can also have bad outcomes.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: Thanks.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: So I would say that—remember the important thing is that we want the federal funds rate to trade in the target range.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: That’s the whole, the whole idea.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: IOER is the principal tool by which we assure that that will happen.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: And we’ve said in our, you know, basic documents that we will adjust the use of our tools, as appropriate.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: We don’t expect to have to do this often or again, but we’re not sure about that.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: If we have to do it again, we’ll do it again.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: Again, don’t expect it to happen.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: You asked why.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: And yes, you know, we—of course, we’re looking carefully at that and, you know, the truth is we don’t—we don’t know with any precision.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: Really, no one does.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: It’s—you can’t run experiments, you know, with one effect and not the other.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: You know, I think there’s a lot of probability on the idea of just high bill supply leads to higher repo costs, higher money market rates generally, and the arbitrage pulls up June 13, 2018 federal funds rate towards IOER.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: We don’t know that that’s the only effect and, you know, Chairman Powell’s Press Conference FINAL we’re just going to have to be watching and learning.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: And, frankly, we don’t have to know today.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: What we really need is to have the federal funds rate trade in the range, and that’s what this minor technical adjustment accomplishes.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
